sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Now. I'm Helena Humphrey. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Russia rejects calls to demilitarize the Zaporizhia nuclear power plant after the UN calls for an urgent end of military activity to prevent a potential disaster.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Serbia and Kosovo fail to reach an agreement on easing tensions between the two countries it talks, mediated by the EU foreign policy chief.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: And Finland's prime minister says she has taken a drugs test after video emerged showing her partying with friends. Sanna Marin vowed she'd never used illegal drugs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Russia has rejected UN calls for a demilitarized zone around the Zaporizhia nuclear power plant,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: which has been in the hands of Russian troops since early March.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Moscow and Kiev have accused each other of shelling the site, which Moscow insists it must protect.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: полномасштабного военного противостояния.

It's too early to say anything about details.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: These are all very sensitive issues.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're now discussing and will continue to discuss the details of the mission, the route, the number of people to be involved, how long they'll stay at the plant and for what tasks they're sent there for.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: NATO Chief Jens Stoltenberg said on Wednesday that the UN's atomic watchdog must be allowed to inspect the plant as a matter of urgency, emphasising that Russia's occupancy of the site increases the risk of nuclear accident.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The plant is the largest of its kind in Europe, and as the battle lines creep closer, many fear a nuclear disaster similar to that of Chernobyl in 1986.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: As tensions rise between Serbia and Kosovo,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: the European Union has been trying to play mediator, but to no avail.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: A meeting yesterday between EU foreign policy chief Joseph Borrell and leaders from the two nations ended without reaching an agreement.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Borrell says it's important for the two nations to normalize their relations, particularly given the current context.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: their relations, particularly given the current context. And this happened at the moment when we are in a critical time for Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We see the return of war to our continent after the Russia invasion of Ukraine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We are facing a dramatic and very dangerous moment for our continent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And this is not a moment for increasing tensions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It is time for looking for solutions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Before meeting with Borrell, the two leaders met separately with NATO leader Jens Stoltenberg.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The latest tension follows Kosovo's decision that Serbian identity documents and vehicle license plates would no longer be valid in its territory.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Belgrade has been implementing the same measures for people from Kosovo crossing into Serbia for years, saying accepting them would amount to recognizing its neighbor as an independent state.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Serbia still refuses to recognize Kosovo's independence declared in 2008.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: refuses to recognize Kosovo's independence, declared in 2008.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Finland's Prime Minister Sanna Marin says she has taken a drug test after a video emerged of her at a party with friends.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: She was pictured at a private residence, Finnish singer Alma, a member of parliament and other celebrities.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Opposition leaders demanded that the 36-year-old took took a test saying a shadow of doubt had been casted over the leader.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I have nothing to hide. I have not used drugs so it's not a problem for me to take a drug test either.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But I find it quite extraordinary that this has been demanded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: I have seen no evidence of any drug use anywhere.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: It is not a problem for me to take a drug test.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The prime minister says the test results will be available in one week. Last year she apologized for visiting a bar after coming into contact with someone who had coronavirus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: She was criticized but ultimately not found to have broken any rules.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Italy's foreign minister Luigi Di Maio has accused former Russian president Dmitry Medvedev

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: of interfering in the country's upcoming general election.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The outgoing government, led by Mario Draghi, has fully backed Western sanctions against Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine. On social media platform Telegram, Medvedev urged Europeans to punish their governments at the polls for what he described as their evident stupidity and repeated threats to cut off Russian gas supplies to the continent.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Enrico Letta, leader of the center-left Democratic Party, also hit out at the post, describing it as a serious case of interference.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Leader of the populist Lega Nord party Matteo Salvini stopped short of condemning the remarks, saying that he's not interested in making controversy with the rest of the world.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Medvedev has openly taken pleasure from the recent political turmoil in the UK and in Italy, which brought about the end to the leadership of Boris Johnson and Mario Draghi, two of Ukraine's most staunch supporters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: The long-time financial chief of Donald Trump's company has pleaded guilty to fraud and tax evasion charges.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Allen Weisselberg had been charged with hiding millions of euros in off-the-books income and will likely be sentenced to prison time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Now, it comes amid a backdrop of legal worries for the former US president after the FBI sees classified documents from his Mar-a-Lago home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, joining us now is Scott Lucas, emeritus professor of US politics at the University of Birmingham in the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Scott, great to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Donald Trump faces a myriad legal issues, really, doesn't he?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: There's worries when it comes to his personal business, concerns about his treatment of classified data, and also his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: So of those three thorns in his side, which thorn looks to be the thorniest, I guess?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: All of them. Sorry to be a bit vague.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We would need a half hour to detail all the legal charges.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But here's how they intercept.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: First of all, the FBI raid actually opens itself up to three possible felony counts, which include prison sentences.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So Trump likely violated the Presidential Records Act by taking documents without permission from the White House.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But those documents were wanted as part of an investigation into the Capitol attack, which Trump is accused of inciting, and so now he faces obstruction of a government investigation charge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And then, of course, some of the documents were the top security classification that the government has, which makes him vulnerable to the Espionage Act.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So you have got that one dimension. But then you mentioned the business practices. And there you have the New York state civil case, to which Trump has recently pleaded the Fifth Amendment for more than four hours, which is looking into fraud in his businesses.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And that investigation may lead to the Manhattan district attorney pursuing a criminal investigation of Trump's business.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: And of course, we know that yesterday, his chief financial officer, the man who was at his side for 40 years at the Trump Organization, Allen Weisselberg, pleaded guilty and will be testifying at a trial involving the Trump Organization in October. And then the third dimension you mentioned the election. Well here's the case to watch for. Down in Georgia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Trump and his allies are accused of trying to put in what's called fake electors fake representatives throwing out the legally elected representatives of Joe Biden.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, look, if you compare it to previous presidents, I mean, people used to call Bill Clinton Teflon Bill. I think Trump has taken that to a whole other level. But nevertheless, is there the sense now and from what you're saying that essentially he is running out of road here, do you think?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The 21st century is an ongoing contest, which is different from Richard Nixon or Bill Clinton because of the extent of disinformation and how fast it spreads.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So it's not as much Teflon, it's throwing mud. And what Trump has done since he ran for president in 2016 is that he's thrown mud, disinformation, whether it was over his connections with Russia, is that he's thrown mud, disinformation, whether it was over his connections with Russia, whether it was over his attempt to blackmail Ukraine to get Joe Biden out of the 2020 election, whether it was over his business and practices and fraud. And this contest will continue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Donald Trump, as soon as the FBI raided his house, in fact, within minutes, was on Truth Social, his media outlet, to say this was all the deep state, it was a witch hunt, it was a plot. And so what you have is, for all the legal analysis I can give you, is this battle for hearts and minds, where Trump is trying to seize them with falsehoods and deceptions, and hoping that the truth never catches up with him.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Thank you.
